questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented to the clinic for a routine check-up last week. He has no significant past medical history, but Automated Office Blood Pressure (AoBP) monitoring showed blood pressure readings of 142/94 mmHg, 138/86 mmHg, and 138/90 mmHg. Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring was advised; the average 24-hour blood pressure is 138/86 mmHg. According to the ACC/AHA hypertension classification, what category does his blood pressure fall into?
questions.explanation:
Hypertension category based on the American College of Cardiology (ACC)

Blood pressure category

Systolic (mm Hg)

Diastolic (mm Hg)

Normal (Option A ruled out)

< 120

< 80

Elevated (Option B ruled out)

120-129

<80

Stage 1 hypertension (Option C)

130 – 139

80 – 89

Stage 2 hypertension (Option D)

≥140

≥90

Hypertensive crisis

>180

>120

Hypertension Diagnosis Based on ABPM (ambulatory blood pressure monitoring)

24-h Average

≥130/80 mm Hg

Awake (daytime) average

≥135/85 mm Hg

Asleep (night-time) average

≥120/70 mm Hg

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a BMI of 30 presents with frequent headaches and dizziness. His office blood pressure is recorded as 126/74 mmHg, but home readings range between 150/94 mmHg and 156/90 mmHg. Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring confirms these findings with higher readings outside the office. Which of the following is the most appropriate management plan for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Increase clinic visit frequency to monitor blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Diagnosis to be reconfirmed in 3 to 6 months

questions.explanation:
ACC/AHA

White coat hypertension

Masked hypertension

Definition

Elevated clinic or office BP and normal out-of-office BP (on ABPM or HBPM) in individuals not receiving antihypertensive therapy

Normal BP on clinic or office BP readings and elevated out-of-office BP readings in individuals not receiving antihypertensive therapy

Diagnosis

Cutoff for Office Blood Pressure: ≥130/80 mmHg

Cutoff for Out-of-Office Blood Pressure (Daytime ABPM or HBPM): <130/80 mmHg

Cutoff for Office Blood Pressure: 120–129/<80 mmHg

Cutoff for Out-of-Office Blood Pressure (Daytime ABPM or HBPM): ≥130/80 mmHg

Management

 
  • Lifestyle measures
  • Diagnosis to be reconfirmed in 3 to 6 months (Option D ruled out)
  • Yearly follow-ups with ABPM to detect progression to sustained hypertension
  • Antihypertensive treatment:
    • Estimated 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk of ≥10%
    • Hypertension-related target organ damage
  • Lifestyle measures + antihypertensive drug therapy recommended (Option B) (Option A ruled out)
  • Long-term out-of-office BP monitoring (Option C ruled out)

Target Organ Damage
  • Increased risk when compared to normotensive
  • Significantly increased risk
  • Cardiovascular risk is similar to that in patients with sustained hypertension

questions.text: During a lecture on cardiovascular physiology, a professor explained that conditions causing unequal arm blood pressure often involve branches of the aortic arch. Which of the following conditions is not likely to cause a difference in blood pressure between the arms?

options.label: A
options.text: Aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta

options.label: B
options.text: Coarctation of the aorta distal to the left subclavian artery

options.label: C
options.text: Takayasu arteritis affecting the aortic arch

questions.correct_answer: B. Coarctation of the aorta distal to the left subclavian artery
questions.explanation:
Conditions causing unequal left and right arm blood pressures

Pathophysiology

Aortic Dissection (Option A)

Dissection occurring at the site of arterial branching from the aorta

Subclavian Artery Stenosis (Option D ruled out)

Atherosclerosis or other causes of stenosis (Thoracic Outlet Syndrome) in the subclavian artery reduce blood flow to the affected arm

Takayasu Arteritis (Option C)

Chronic vasculitis that affects large arteries, particularly the aorta and its branches

Coarctation of the Aorta

Congenital narrowing of the aorta affecting branches of the aorta and narrowing proximal to left subclavian artery (Option C)

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with a history of resistant hypertension and periodic muscle cramps is being investigated. Lab tests show hypokalemia, low plasma renin activity, and low aldosterone levels. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Mode of inheritance

Pathophysiology

Key Features

Liddle syndrome (Option B)

Autosomal dominant

Hyperactive ENaC reabsorbs sodium at elevated levels, resulting in volume expansion and hypertension
  • Hypokalemia
  • Low renin
  • Low aldosterone

Gordan syndrome

(Pseudohypoaldosteronism type II) (Option A ruled out)

Autosomal dominant

Mutations in regulatory proteins for the NCC (sodium chloride cotransporter) channel allow for unchecked activity, causing subsequent electrolyte and fluid overabsorption
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Normal glomerular filtration rate

Polycystic kidneys

Autosomal dominant

Large cystic kidneys
  • Renal failure
  • Liver cysts
  • Cerebral aneurysms
  • Valvular heart disease

Pheochromocytoma (Option D ruled out)

Autosomal dominant

Neoplasia of the adrenal medulla generates heightened levels of norepinephrine and epinephrine

Associated with

  • MEN-2A (Sipple syndrome)
  • MEN-2B
  • VHL syndrome
  • NF-1

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) (Option C ruled out)

Autosomal recessive

Defects in steroid synthesis lead to buildup of intermediate metabolites with mineralocorticoid receptor activity
  • 17-α hydroxylase deficiency: ↑ in aldosterone and thus HTN
  • 11-β hydroxylase deficiency: ↑ in deoxycortisol which stimulates ENaC and causes HTN

Glucocorticoid-
remediable hyperaldosteronism

Autosomal dominant

Chimeric 11β-hydroxylase/aldosterone gene
  • Absent or mild hypokalemia

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a long-standing history of hypertension presents with occasional episodes of dizziness and transient visual disturbances. Neurological examination and fundoscopy are normal. A carotid ultrasound is performed to visualize the carotid arteries. Which of the following findings is not expected to be seen in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Atherosclerotic plaque formation in the carotid arteries

options.label: D
options.text: Turbulent blood flow in the carotid arteries

questions.explanation:
Complications of HTN

Heart disease
  • Most common cause of death in hypertensive patients
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy

Brain disease
  • The second most frequent cause of death
  • Ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes

Kidney disease
  • Decrease in eGFR
  • Chronic kidney disease (Option B)

Arterial disease (Options A, C & D ruled out)
  • Carotid arteries: Atherosclerotic plaque/stenosis (turbulent flow of blood) and intima-media thickness
  • Aorta: Artery stiffening, aortic dissection
  • Peripheral artery disease in lower extremity: Claudication symptom

Eye disease
  • Hypertensive retinopathy

questions.text: A 70-year-old Indian-origin male with a history of hypertension not on medications has chronic kidney disease (stage 2). His laboratory tests indicate an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 60 mL/min and elevated protein in his urine. His present blood pressure is 142/90 mmHg. Considering his condition, which of the following antihypertensive medications is most appropriate to initiate?
questions.explanation:
ACC/AHA Guidelines for Hypertension Management

Indications for Use of antihypertensives

Secondary prevention of recurrent CVD events in patients with clinical CVD (defined as CHD, CHF, stroke) and BP ≥130/≥80 mmHg

Primary prevention in patients with an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk ≥10% and BP ≥130/≥80 mmHg

Primary prevention of CVD and low CVD risk in patients with BP ≥140/ ≥90 mmHg

Blood Pressure Goal in Treating Hypertension

BP target < 130/80 mmHg for adults with confirmed hypertension and known CVD or 10-year ASCVD event risk ≥10%

Exceptions to Therapeutic Target of <130/80 mmHg

Age >80 years

Blood pressure <140/90 mmHg in previously untreated hypertensive patients who experience an ischemic stroke or TIA

Acute therapy for most hypertensive urgencies and emergencies

Patient type

First Drug

Add a Second Drug If Needed to Achieve the target BP

If a Third Drug is Needed to Achieve the target BP

Black patients (African ancestry): All ages

CCB or thiazide diuretic

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Combination of CCB + ACE inhibitor or ARB + thiazide diuretic

 

White and other non-black Patients: Younger than 60 years

ARB or ACE inhibitor

CCB or thiazide diuretic 

White and other non-black patients: 60 years and older

CCB or thiazide diuretic

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension with other associated conditions

Initial drug of choice

Hypertension and diabetes

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension and chronic kidney disease (Option B) (Options A & C ruled out)

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Note: in black patients, good evidence for the renal protective effects of ACE inhibitors

Hypertension and clinical coronary artery disease (Option D ruled out)

β-Blocker plus ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension and stroke history

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension and heart failure

Regardless of blood pressure, ARB or ACE inhibitor + β-blocker + diuretic + spironolactone. A dihydropyridine CCB can be added if needed for BP control.

Pneumonic: ABDS

questions.text: As a medicine resident, you are counselling a newly diagnosed hypertensive patient on lifestyle modifications to promote better health and help manage her blood pressure. Which of the following recommendations would be inappropriate or misleading for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Brisk walking for 15 mins/day, 5 days a week

questions.correct_answer: A. Brisk walking for 15 mins/day, 5 days a week
questions.explanation:
Hypertension lifestyle modifications

Weight reduction
  • BMI < 25kg/m2 (Option C ruled out)

Dietary salt reduction
  • <6g NaCl/day (Option B ruled out)

DASH-type dietary plan (Option D ruled out)
  • A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products with reduced saturated and total fat content.
  • Diet is also rich in potassium, calcium, and magnesium.

Moderation of alcohol consumption
  • ≤2 drinks/day in men and ≤1 drink/day in women

Physical activity
  • Regular aerobic activity, e.g., brisk walking for 30 min/day for 5 days a week. (Option A)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe headache, nausea, and confusion. His blood pressure is recorded at 190/130 mmHg. Neurological examination reveals altered mental status, and the patient appears distressed. A fundoscopic exam shows retinal haemorrhages. What is the most appropriate classification of this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Features

Treatment Approach

Hypertensive Urgency
  • Systolic BP > 180 mmHg and/or Diastolic BP > 120 mmHg without end-organ damage
  • Stable patients, often noncompliant or discontinued therapy (Option A)
  • Reinstitution or increase of oral antihypertensives
  • No hospitalization required
  • Gradual BP reduction over hours/days

Hypertensive Emergency
  • The same BP values as urgency but with end-organ damage
  • Examples:
    • Encephalopathy, stroke
    • Retinal haemorrhages
    • Aortic dissection
    • MAHA
  • Immediate 25% reduction in BP using IV agents (e.g., nitroprusside, nicardipine, labetalol)

Malignant Hypertension
  • Severe hypertension (BP > 180/120) with 3 or more target organ damage (Option C)
  • It is a type of hypertensive emergency but with 3 or > 3 target organ damage
  • Abrupt increase in BP in previously hypertensive or sudden onset in normotensive
  • Values of BP are not important but it's the rapid rise and target organ damage which is important
  • Pathology
    • Diffuse necrotizing vasculitis, arterial thrombi, fibrin deposition in arterioles
    • Fibrinoid necrosis in kidneys, brain, retina, etc.
  • Intensive management often requires hospitalization and aggressive therapy

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents to his primary care physician for a follow-up appointment. His blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg. The physician wants to start an antihypertensive medication. What is the target blood pressure for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Target Blood Pressure

Recommended Medications

General Hypertension

< 135-140/85-90 mmHg

Initial: Thiazide diuretic, CCB, ACEI, or ARB (non-black); Thiazide or CCB (black)

Hypertension with Diabetic Nephropathy

< 130/80 mmHg (Option C)

ACEI/ARB

Malignant Hypertension

Reduce MAP by 20-25% over 2 hours

Nitroprusside, labetalol, fenoldepam

End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD)

< 130/80 mmHg

CCB (e.g., Amlodipine), Alpha blocker

Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) Grade I-III

< 130/80 mmHg

ACEI/ARB + Thiazide + CCB

eGFR < 30 ml/min

< 130/80 mmHg

Diuretics (e.g., Metolazone)

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the image given?

options.label: A
options.text: Can help identify the white-coat effect in patients

options.label: B
options.text: Continuous readings for a full 24-hour period

options.label: C
options.text: Measures both awake and sleep averages

questions.correct_answer: D. Used to investigate hypertension only
questions.explanation:
Parameter

Ambulatory BP Monitoring (ABPM)

Home Blood Pressure Monitoring (HBPM)

Device Type

Oscillometric

Oscillometric

Operation

Worn by patient, preprogrammed, fully automatic

Self-administered by the patient

Monitoring Duration

24 hours (Option B ruled out)

7 days (morning and evening)

Data Transfer

Transfers data to computer for report generation

Patient documents and shares readings at discretion

Mean Overall BP

Present in report

Average of 6 days if > 135/85 mmHg

Mean Awake BP

Present in report

Average of readings during the day

Mean Sleep BP

Present in the report (Option C ruled out)

Not typically calculated

Nocturnal Dip

Yes (percentage reduction at night)

Not applicable

Morning Surge

Yes

Not applicable

BP Load

Yes (percentage of readings above threshold)

Not applicable

HTN Criteria (Awake BP)

> 135/85 mmHg

> 135/85 mmHg

HTN Criteria (Sleep BP)

> 120/75 mmHg

Not applicable

Clinical Applications
  • White-coat hypertension (Option A ruled out)
  • Confirm hypertension in children
  • Resistant hypertension
  • Labile hypertension
  • Hypotensive episodes (Option D)

Self-monitoring for hypertension management
